title: 106_hr2397
content: The Act is titled the "Paycheck Fairness Act" and references the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938. It includes findings related to pay equity. Congress finds that women entering the workforce in record numbers still face significantly lower pay than men for equal work, leading to wage depression for families and underutilization of labor resources. Pay disparities persist due to intentional discrimination or past biases. Congress finds that labor resources are being spread among workers through commerce, burdening and obstructing the free flow of goods, leading to unfair competition and labor disputes. This interference with commerce may deprive workers of equal protection based on sex. Artificial barriers hinder the elimination of these issues. Artificial barriers to wage discrimination based on sex persist despite decades since the enactment of the Fair Labor Standards Act and Civil Rights Act. Removing these barriers would benefit the economy, reduce reliance on public assistance, promote family stability, and address past discrimination effects. The Equal Pay Act of 1963 aims to address past discrimination and ensure equal protection for workers based on sex in the private sector. Increased information and effective remedies will help women enforce their rights to equal pay for equal work. Some employers have already made progress in eliminating unfair pay disparities. SEC. 3. ENHANCED ENFORCEMENT OF EQUAL PAY REQUIREMENTS. Section 6(d)(1) (29 U.S.C. 206(d)(1)) is amended to allow for a pay differential based on factors other than sex, such as education, training, or experience, if the employer can demonstrate that it is job-related or serves a legitimate business purpose. The employer can justify a pay differential based on factors other than sex, as long as it is job-related or serves a legitimate business purpose. If the employer can demonstrate this, they cannot reduce wages to comply with the law. The provisions of this subsection apply to applicants as well. The subsection provisions apply to employment applicants and eliminate the establishment requirement for employees. The nonretaliation provision is amended to include applicants for employment. The nonretaliation provision is amended to include applicants for employment. Section 16(b) is amended to impose enhanced penalties for violations of section 6(d), including compensatory or punitive damages. The text chunk amends provisions related to class actions and liability enforcement under Federal law. It includes changes to sentences regarding employee actions and the ability to maintain class actions to enforce section 6(d) as per the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. The text chunk amends provisions related to liability enforcement under Federal law, including expert fees. It also addresses compensatory or punitive damages for violations of section 6(d) in employee actions. The text chunk modifies liability enforcement provisions under Federal law, including expert fees and compensatory or punitive damages for violations of section 6(d) in employee actions. It amends specific sentences and adds new conditions for class action lawsuits. SEC. 4. TRAINING. The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and the Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs will provide training on discrimination in wage payment. SEC. 5. RESEARCH, EDUCATION, AND OUTREACH. The Secretary of Labor will conduct studies and provide information to address pay disparities between men and women by promoting research, publishing findings, sponsoring educational programs, and providing information to various organizations and the public. The Secretary of Labor will address pay disparities by engaging with organizations, promoting achievements of those working to eliminate disparities, and convening a national summit to discuss solutions. SEC. 6. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AND EMPLOYER RECOGNITION PROGRAM. The Secretary of Labor will develop guidelines for employers to evaluate job categories based on objective criteria such as educational requirements, skill levels, working conditions, and responsibilities. These guidelines aim to help employers compare wages for different jobs to address unfair pay disparities between occupations traditionally dominated by men or women. The Secretary of Labor will establish guidelines for employers to evaluate job categories and publish them in the Federal Register within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Employers who adjust wage scales based on voluntary job evaluations to reflect the real value of women's contributions will be recognized for their efforts. The Secretary of Labor will establish guidelines for employers to evaluate job categories and publish them in the Federal Register. Employers must adjust wage scales to ensure fair pay for women compared to men. The Secretary of Labor will promulgate necessary rules and regulations for implementation. Technical assistance may be provided to employers for evaluation purposes. Establishment of the National Award for Pay Equity in the Workplace. The Robert Reich National Award for Pay Equity in the Workplace is established, with specific criteria for businesses to qualify for the award by demonstrating efforts to eliminate pay disparities between men and women. Additional requirements may also apply as prescribed by the Secretary of Labor. The President or designated representative presents the annual award to businesses meeting qualifications determined by the Secretary of Labor. The award ceremony is conducted as deemed appropriate. The term "business" includes corporations, partnerships, and nonprofit corporations. Entities eligible for the annual award include corporations, partnerships, professional associations, labor organizations, and similar business entities. Additionally, entities conducting education or training programs, as well as joint programs formed by a combination of eligible entities, are also eligible. SEC. 8. COLLECTION OF PAY INFORMATION BY THE EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION. Section 709 of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 is amended to require the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission to conduct a survey on employee pay data for enforcing laws against pay discrimination and issue regulations for collecting pay information based on sex, race, and national origin of employees. The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission must prioritize enhancing enforcement of laws against pay discrimination, considering factors like employer burdens, report frequency, data confidentiality, and effective data collection formats. SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS: Sums may be appropriated as necessary for this Act.
